facts.text: These appeals are directed against an order dated 9th March, 2007 passed by the High Court of Judicature, Andhra Pradesh at Hyderabad.

anchor.surface_text: order dated 9th March, 2007 passed by the High Court of Judicature, Andhra Pradesh at Hyderabad whereby the High Court has set aside the order passed by the State Administrate Tribunal in OA No.6334 of 1997

facts.text: High Court set aside the order passed by the State Administrative Tribunal in OA No.6334 of 1997 to the extent the same holds the judgment of this Court in V. Jagannadha Rao and Ors. v. State of Andhra Pradesh and Ors. 2001 10 SCC 401, to be prospective in its application.

anchor.surface_text: whereby the High Court has set aside the order passed by the State Administrate Tribunal in OA No.6334 of 1997 to the extent the same holds the judgment of this Court in V. Jagannadha Rao and Ors. v. State of Andhra Pradesh and Ors.  2001  10 SCC 401, to be prospective in its application.

facts.text: An order dated 3rd November, 2010 passed by the High Court dismissing a review petition filed by the appellants against the said order has also been assailed.

anchor.surface_text: . An order dated 3rd November, 2010 passed by the High Court dismissing a review petition filed by the appellants against the said order has also been assailed.

facts.text: In V. Jagannadha Rao and Ors. v. State of Andhra Pradesh and Ors. 2001 10 SCC 401, a three-Judge Bench was examining whether Special Rules framed by the Governor of Andhra Pradesh under proviso to Article 309 of the Constitution permitted appointment by transfer to a higher category on the basis of seniority-cum-efficiency were violative of para 5 2 of the Presidential Order issued under Article 371-D.

anchor.surface_text: In V. Jagannadha Rao and Ors. v. State of Andhra Pradesh and Ors.  2001  10 SCC 401, a three-Judge Bench was examining whether Special Rules framed by the Governor of Andhra Pradesh under proviso to Article 309 of the Constitution to the extent the same permitted appointment by transfer to a higher category on the basis of seniority-cum-efficiency were violative of para 5  2  of the Presidential Order issued under Article 371-D of the Constitution of India, 1950.

facts.text: Presidential Order dated 18th October, 1975 issued under Article 371-D of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: Answering the question in the affirmative this Court held that the Presidential Order dated 18th October, 1975 issued under Article 371-D of the Constitution was aimed at providing equitable opportunities and facilities to the people belonging to different parts of the State in the matter of public employment, education etc.

facts.text: GOMs No.72 dated 25th February, 1986 and GOMs No.117 dated 28th May, 1986 made UDCs in the Labour Department and those working in Factories and Boilers Department eligible for recruitment by transfer to the posts of Assistant Inspectors of Labour and Assistant Inspectors of Factories.

anchor.surface_text: The question had arisen on account of a challenge mounted by the Ministerial employees of the Labour Department against GOMs No.72 dated 25th February, 1986 and GOMs No.117 dated 28th May, 1986 whereunder UDCs in the Labour Department and those working in Factories and Boilers Department were made eligible for recruitment by transfer to the posts of Assistant Inspectors of Labour and Assistant Inspectors of Factories.

facts.text: A full Bench of Tribunal declared that the impugned Rules to the extent they enabled the Ministerial employees of the Factories and Boilers Department or any other department to be considered for appointment to the posts in the Labour Department were violative of paras 3 and 5 of the Presidential Order and hence void.

anchor.surface_text: A full Bench of Tribunal before whom the challenge came up for consideration declared that the impugned Rules to the extent they enabled the Ministerial employees of the Factories and Boilers Department or any other department to be considered for appointment to the posts in the Labour Department were violative of paras 3 and 5 of the Presidential Order and hence void.

facts.text: This Court in V. Jagannadha Rao dismissed the appeals and held that local cadre was the unit under para 5 1 for recruitment, appointment, seniority, promotion and transfers.

anchor.surface_text: Dismissing the appeals, this Court held that according to the scheme of the Presidential Order, local cadre was the unit under para 5  1  thereof for recruitment, appointment, seniority, promotion and transfers.

facts.text: The present batch of cases relates to G.O.M. No.14, Labour Employment Training Ser. IV Department, dated 26th November, 1994, as amended by G.O.M. No.22 dated 9th May, 1996.

anchor.surface_text: The current controversy does not relate to GOMs No.72 dated 25th February, 1986 and GOMs No.117 dated 28th May, 1986 which fell for consideration before this Court in V. Jagannadha Raos case  supra . The case at hand arises out of slightly different though essentially similar circumstances. The present batch of cases relates to G.O.M. No.14, Labour Employment Training  Ser. IV  Department, dated 26th November, 1994, as amended by G.O.M. No.22 dated 9th May, 1996.

facts.text: G.O.M. No.14 dated 26th November, 1994 as amended by G.O.M. No.22 dated 9th May, 1996 provide that Senior Assistants and Senior Stenographers working in the Head Offices shall also be eligible for appointment by transfer to the post of Assistant Labour Officer.

anchor.surface_text: These two G.O.Ms. provide that while Senior Assistants and Senior Stenographers working in the Subordinate Offices of the Labour Department constitute the feeding channel under Rule 3 of Andhra Pradesh Labour Subordinate Service Rules, Senior Assistants and Senior Stenographers working in the Head Offices shall also be eligible for appointment by transfer to the post of Assistant Labour Officer.

facts.text: Employees approached the Andhra Pradesh Administrative Tribunal aggrieved by the G.O.Ms.

anchor.surface_text: Aggrieved by the G.O.Ms. some of the employees approached the Andhra Pradesh Administrative Tribunal for redressal.

facts.text: Tribunal partly allowed petitions by order dated 7th March, 2003 and struck down G.O.M. No.14 dated 26th November, 1994 as amended to the extent it provided channel for certain categories for appointment by transfer to Assistant Labour Officer.

anchor.surface_text: These petitions were partly allowed by the Tribunal in terms of its order dated 7th March, 2003 and G.O.M. No.14, dated 26th November, 1994, as amended by G.O.M. No.22 dated 9th May, 1996 struck down as unconstitutional to the extent the same provided a channel for Senior Assistant and Senior Stenographer in Andhra Pradesh Ministerial Service working in the Head Offices of Labour Department and those in Factories and Boiler Departments besides those in the Subordinate Offices in the said Departments for appointment by transfer to the post of Assistant Labour Officer.

facts.text: Tribunal directed that the striking down would only be prospective and no action taken till 7th November, 2001 disturbed and no employee promoted reverted.

anchor.surface_text: Having said that the Tribunal directed that the striking down of the impugned O.Ms. would only be prospective and that any action taken in compliance with the said Rules till 7th November, 2001 shall not be disturbed nor any employee promoted on the basis of the legal position that prevailed earlier to the decision of this Court in V. Jagannadha Raos case  supra  reverted.

facts.text: Writ Petitions No.6163 and 6068 of 2004 filed challenging the judgment of the Tribunal to the extent it saved the promotions already made.

anchor.surface_text: The aggrieved employees, who had approached the Tribunal having succeeded but only in part, filed Writ Petitions No.6163 and 6068 of 2004 whereby they challenged the judgment of the Tribunal to the extent it saved the promotions already made on the basis of the impugned G.O.Ms.

facts.text: Writ Petition No.16890 of 2006 filed against the judgment by employees aggrieved by the view that G.O.Ms. were unconstitutional.

anchor.surface_text: Writ Petition No.16890 of 2006 was also filed against the very same judgment by some of the employees who felt aggrieved by the view taken by the Tribunal that the impugned G.O.Ms. were in violation of the Presidential Order hence unconstitutional.

facts.text: Division Bench of High Court allowed Writ Petitions No.6163 and 6068 of 2004 but dismissed No.16890 of 2006 by order dated 9th March, 2007.

anchor.surface_text: A Division Bench of the High Court of Andhra Pradesh has, in terms of the judgment and order under challenge before us, allowed Writ Petitions No.6123 and 6068 of 2004 but dismissed Writ Petition No.16890 of 2006 relying upon certain decisions rendered by this Court.

facts.text: High Court held that doctrine of prospective overruling could be invoked only by Apex Court not by High Courts under Article 226.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has taken the view that the doctrine of prospective overruling could be invoked only by the Apex Court and not by other Court including High Courts exercising powers under Article 226 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Appellants filed Review WPMP No.3576 of 2010 contending they were not impleaded though affected.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants in these appeals are employees who were not arrayed as parties to the writ petition filed before the High Court. Feeling aggrieved of the judgment and order passed by the High Court they filed Review WPMP No.3576 of 2010, inter alia, contending that the judgment under review had been passed without impleading employees like the appellants as parties to the case even though they were bound to be adversely affected by any modification that the High Court may have made.

facts.text: High Court dismissed review petitions on 3rd November, 2010.

anchor.surface_text: The review petitions were, accordingly, dismissed and the prayer for grant of leave to appeal to this Court rejected.

facts.text: V. Jagannadha Rao judgment pronounced on 7th November, 2001.

anchor.surface_text: no promotion had been made after the 7th November, 2001, the date when the judgment of this Court in Jagannadha Raos case  supra  was pronounced.

facts.text: Tribunal order dated 27th March, 2003 struck down rules but saved promotions already made.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal had on the authority of the judgment aforementioned struck down the rules providing for ex-cadre zone promotions by its order dated 27th March, 2003, but saved the promotions already made.

facts.text: State Administrative Tribunal declared rule providing for inter-department transfer by promotion bad by order dated 17th April, 1995 in Jagannadha Rao case.

anchor.surface_text: In Jagannadha Raos case  supra , the petitions were filed in the year 1987. The State Administrative Tribunal had declared the rule providing for inter-department transfer by promotion to be bad by its order dated 17th April, 1995.

facts.text: Petitions in present case filed before Tribunal in 1997.

anchor.surface_text: The petitions in the present case were filed before the State Administrative Tribunal in the year 1997.

facts.text: Promotions made before 7th November, 2001 continued for nearly ten years till review dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: Promotions made before the pronouncement of the order in Jagannadha Raos case  supra  i.e. before 7th November, 2001 have, thus, continued for nearly ten years till the review petition filed by the petitioners was dismissed and the matter brought up before this Court.

facts.text: Appellants are employees promoted under the impugned rules who were not parties to the writ petitions.

issues.text: whether Special Rules framed by the Governor of Andhra Pradesh under proviso to Article 309 of the Constitution to the extent the same permitted appointment by transfer to a higher category on the basis of seniority-cum-efficiency were violative of para 5(2) of the Presidential Order issued under Article 371-D of the Constitution of India, 1950

anchor.surface_text: In V. Jagannadha Rao and Ors. v. State of Andhra Pradesh and Ors. 2001 10 SCC 401, a three-Judge Bench was examining whether Special Rules framed by the Governor of Andhra Pradesh under proviso to Article 309 of the Constitution to the extent the same permitted appointment by transfer

issues.text: whether G.O.M. No.14 dated 26th November, 1994 as amended by G.O.M. No.22 dated 9th May, 1996 providing that Senior Assistants and Senior Stenographers working in Head Offices shall be eligible for appointment by transfer to the post of Assistant Labour Officer (zonal post) were violative of paras 3(3) and 5(1) of the Presidential Order

anchor.surface_text: The present batch of cases relates to G.O.M. No.14, Labour Employment Training Ser. IV Department, dated 26th November, 1994, as amended by G.O.M. No.22 dated 9th May, 1996. These two G.O.Ms. provide that while Senior Assistants and Senior Stenographers working in the Subordinate Offices of the Labour Department constitute the feeding channel under Rule 3 of Andhra Pradesh Labour Subordinate Service Rules, Senior Assistants and Senior Stenographers working in the Head Offices shall also be eligible for appointment by transfer to the post of Assistant Labour Officer.

issues.text: whether the term 'transfer' in para 5(2) of the Presidential Order includes promotion

anchor.surface_text: Dismissing the appeals, this Court held that according to the scheme of the Presidential Order, local cadre was the unit under para 5 1 thereof for recruitment, appointment, seniority, promotion and transfers. This Court further held that while para 5 2 authorised the State Government to make provisions for transfer in certain specified circumstances, yet the term transfer could not be enlarged in its amplitude so as to include promotional aspects.

issues.text: whether the doctrine of prospective overruling could be invoked only by the Apex Court and not by other courts including High Courts exercising powers under Article 226 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has taken the view that the doctrine of prospective overruling could be invoked only by the Apex Court and not by other Court including High Courts exercising powers under Article 226 of the Constitution. The net effect of the view taken by the High Court, therefore, is that not only are the impugned G.O.M. held to be unconstitutional, but any action taken pursuant thereto is also declared to be unconstitutional.

holdings.text: Special Rules framed under Article 309 permitting appointment by transfer to higher category on basis of seniority-cum-efficiency are violative of para 5(2) of Presidential Order under Article 371-D

anchor.surface_text: In V. Jagannadha Rao and Ors. v. State of Andhra Pradesh and Ors. 2001 10 SCC 401, a three-Judge Bench was examining whether Special Rules framed by the Governor of Andhra Pradesh under proviso to Article 309 of the Constitution to the extent the same permitted appointment by transfer to a higher category on the basis of seniority-cum-efficiency were violative of para 5 2  of the Presidential Order issued under Article 371-D of the Constitution of India, 1950.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Answering in affirmative as Presidential Order ensures equitable opportunities in public employment; rules subordinate and violative

holdings.text: Local cadre is the unit under para 5(1) of Presidential Order for recruitment, appointment, seniority, promotion and transfers

anchor.surface_text: Dismissing the appeals, this Court held that according to the scheme of the Presidential Order, local cadre was the unit under para 5 1  thereof for recruitment, appointment, seniority, promotion and transfers.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme of Presidential Order defines local cadre as operational unit for all public employment processes

holdings.text: Term 'transfer' in para 5(2) of Presidential Order does not include promotion; distinction in para 5(1) applies via harmonious construction

anchor.surface_text: This Court further held that while para 5 2  authorised the State Government to make provisions for transfer in certain specified circumstances, yet the term transfer could not be enlarged in its amplitude so as to include promotional aspects.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statute read as whole; distinction between transfer and promotion in para 5(1) not inadvertent; intention from language used

holdings.text: Presidential Order under Article 371-D(10) prevails over rules framed under Article 309 proviso

anchor.surface_text: in terms of Article 371-D 10 of the Constitution any order made by the President shall have effect notwithstanding anything in any other provision of the Constitution or in any law for the time being in force.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicit overriding effect in clause (10); rules liable to be struck down if violative

holdings.text: G.O.M. No.14 dated 26.11.1994 as amended by G.O.M. No.22 dated 9.5.1996 violative of Presidential Order paras 3(3) and 5(1) to extent permitting non-zonal Senior Assistants/Stenographers for appointment by transfer to zonal Assistant Labour Officer posts

anchor.surface_text: The present batch of cases relates to G.O.M. No.14, Labour Employment Training Ser. IV Department, dated 26th November, 1994, as amended by G.O.M. No.22 dated 9th May, 1996. These two G.O.Ms. provide that while Senior Assistants and Senior Stenographers working in the Subordinate Offices of the Labour Department constitute the feeding channel under Rule 3 of Andhra Pradesh Labour Subordinate Service Rules, Senior Assistants and Senior Stenographers working in the Head Offices shall also be eligible for appointment by transfer to the post of Assistant Labour Officer.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Analogous to V. Jagannadha Rao; provisions like those in impugned rules constitutionally impermissible per Presidential Order

holdings.text: Doctrine of prospective overruling invocable by Supreme Court under Articles 32(4), 142 to mould relief and do complete justice

anchor.surface_text: As a matter of fact Articles 32 4 and 142 are designed with words of width to enable the Supreme Court to declare the law and to give such directions or pass such orders as are necessary to do complete justice.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Historical application from Golak Nath; constituent power transcendental; moulds relief equitably despite unconstitutionality

holdings.text: Doctrine of prospective overruling invoked in this case to save promotions made under impugned G.O.Ms. prior to 7th November 2001; no disturbance or reversion
holdings.reasoning_summary: Law in flux pre-VJR; no post-judgment promotions; long-standing positions (10 years); cascading reversion injustice; appointees not parties; equity under Art 142

anchor.surface_text: Such being the position, we see no reason why the doctrine of prospective overruling cannot be invoked in the instant case. Just because, this Court had not addressed that question in Jagannadha Raos case supra is also no reason for us to refuse to do so in the present case. That apart, Jagannadha Raos case supra was dealing with a different set of terms comprising GoMs No.14 and 22 referred to earlier. While the basic question whether such GoMs permitting promotion by transfer from one department to the cadre or zone to another may have been the same, it cannot be denied that the rules with which this Court was concerned in Jagannadha Raos case supra were different from those with which we are dealing in the present case.

anchor.surface_text: In V. Jagannadha Rao and Ors. v. State of Andhra Pradesh and Ors. 2001 10 SCC 401, a three-Judge Bench was examining whether Special Rules framed by the Governor of Andhra Pradesh under proviso to Article 309 of the Constitution to the extent the same permitted appointment by transfer to a higher category on the basis of seniority-cum-efficiency were violative of para 5 2  of the Presidential Order issued under Article 371-D of the Constitution of India, 1950.

Such being the position, we see no reason why the doctrine of prospective overruling cannot be invoked in the instant case. Just because, this Court had not addressed that question in Jagannadha Raos case supra is also no reason for us to refuse to do so in the present case. That apart, Jagannadha Raos case supra was dealing with a different set of terms comprising GoMs No.14 and 22 referred to earlier. While the basic question whether such GoMs permitting promotion by transfer from one department to the cadre or zone to another may have been the same, it cannot be denied that the rules with which this Court was concerned in Jagannadha Raos case supra were different from those with which we are dealing in the present case.

edges.explanation: h2 on local cadre as unit under para 5(1) supports h5's violation finding under para 5(1) (linked with 3(3))

anchor.surface_text: Dismissing the appeals, this Court held that according to the scheme of the Presidential Order, local cadre was the unit under para 5 1  thereof for recruitment, appointment, seniority, promotion and transfers.

Such being the position, we see no reason why the doctrine of prospective overruling cannot be invoked in the instant case. Just because, this Court had not addressed that question in Jagannadha Raos case supra is also no reason for us to refuse to do so in the present case. That apart, Jagannadha Raos case supra was dealing with a different set of terms comprising GoMs No.14 and 22 referred to earlier. While the basic question whether such GoMs permitting promotion by transfer from one department to the cadre or zone to another may have been the same, it cannot be denied that the rules with which this Court was concerned in Jagannadha Raos case supra were different from those with which we are dealing in the present case.

anchor.surface_text: This Court further held that while para 5 2  authorised the State Government to make provisions for transfer in certain specified circumstances, yet the term transfer could not be enlarged in its amplitude so as to include promotional aspects.

Such being the position, we see no reason why the doctrine of prospective overruling cannot be invoked in the instant case. Just because, this Court had not addressed that question in Jagannadha Raos case supra is also no reason for us to refuse to do so in the present case. That apart, Jagannadha Raos case supra was dealing with a different set of terms comprising GoMs No.14 and 22 referred to earlier. anchor.surface_text: The present batch of cases relates to G.O.M. No.14, Labour Employment Training Ser. IV Department, dated 26th November, 1994, as amended by G.O.M. No.22 dated 9th May, 1996. These two G.O.Ms. provide that while Senior Assistants and Senior Stenographers working in the Subordinate Offices of the Labour Department constitute the feeding channel under Rule 3 of Andhra Pradesh Labour Subordinate Service Rules, Senior Assistants and Senior Stenographers working in the Head Offices shall also be eligible for appointment by transfer to the post of Assistant Labour Officer.

Such being the position, we see no reason why the doctrine of prospective overruling cannot be invoked in the instant case. Just because, this Court had not addressed that question in Jagannadha Raos case supra is also no reason for us to refuse to do so in the present case. That apart, Jagannadha Raos case supra was dealing with a different set of terms comprising GoMs No.14 and 22 referred to earlier. While the basic question whether such GoMs permitting promotion by transfer from one department to the cadre or zone to another may have been the same, it cannot be denied that the rules with which this Court was concerned in Jagannadha Raos case supra were different from those with which we are dealing in the present case.

anchor.surface_text: As a matter of fact Articles 32 4 and 142 are designed with words of width to enable the Supreme Court to declare the law and to give such directions or pass such orders as are necessary to do complete justice.

Such being the position, we see no reason why the doctrine of prospective overruling cannot be invoked in the instant case. Just because, this Court had not addressed that question in Jagannadha Raos case supra is also no reason for us to refuse to do so in the present case. That apart, Jagannadha Raos case supra was dealing with a different set of terms comprising GoMs No.14 and 22 referred to earlier. While the basic question whether such GoMs permitting promotion by transfer from one department to the cadre or zone to another may have been the same, it cannot be denied that the rules with which this Court was concerned in Jagannadha Raos case supra were different from those with which we are dealing in the present case.

Such being the position, we see no reason why the doctrine of prospective overruling cannot be invoked in the instant case. Just because, this Court had not addressed that question in Jagannadha Raos case supra is also no reason for us to refuse to do so in the present case. That apart, Jagannadha Raos case supra was dealing with a different set of terms comprising GoMs No.14 and 22 referred to earlier. While the basic question whether such GoMs permitting promotion by transfer from one department to the cadre or zone to another may have been the same, it cannot be denied that the rules with which this Court was concerned in Jagannadha Raos case supra were different from those with which we are dealing in the present case.
